storyInfo: When a Sankta asks the Lateran Pope: why does the Church refuse to offer others salvation? The answer he receives is that of silence. Perhaps that is a better answer than the real one.

attributes.content: Urgh...
attributes.name: Patia

attributes.content: That's enough, Patia.
attributes.name: Fiammetta

attributes.content: It's... not over...
attributes.name: Patia

attributes.content: Patia, right?
attributes.name: Mostima

attributes.content: Most of the Gun-Knights have been reassigned to the envoys' village. Your mission is over.
attributes.name: Mostima

attributes.content: I don't really get it, though. It's not like Andoain doesn't know who the most powerful guy in the Basilica is... Why the whole charade?
attributes.name: Mostima

attributes.content: He probably wanted to make sure he got an audience with His Holiness.
attributes.name: Fiammetta

attributes.content: Hm? You were actually listening to Lemuen?
attributes.name: Mostima

attributes.content: This has nothing to do with that.
attributes.name: Fiammetta

attributes.content: He is free to settle his score.
attributes.name: Fiammetta

attributes.content: But that doesn't mean I'm letting him get away.
attributes.name: Fiammetta

attributes.content: Sure. Shall we get going?
attributes.name: Mostima

attributes.content: Once we get Patia settled in.
attributes.name: Fiammetta

attributes.content: Right.
attributes.name: Mostima

attributes.content: How should we face this Revelation? These mysterious, indescribable moments; these ambiguous, yet to be explained urges; these unascribable, esoteric intuitions...
attributes.name: The Pope

attributes.content: Where will it lead us? What kind of choice does it want us to make? Or, perhaps, this is merely a hallucination caused by the fatigue of life?
attributes.name: The Pope

attributes.content: But Revelation is called as such only because we willingly believe in it or were told to believe in it.
attributes.name: The Pope

attributes.content: We could even say that if we knew it to be absolutely temporal, even if we deconstructed it into ice cold, objective logic...
attributes.name: The Pope

attributes.content: Regrettably, man will still shine a spiritual light upon 'Revelation.'
attributes.name: The Pope

attributes.content: Thus, when this cruel reality befalls us, the cowards can point fingers at the ambiguity of the Revelation, while the devout can repent their insufficient understanding. In any case, we can at the very least ascertain that we ourselves are not the root cause of everything.
Ah, Andoain. I was expecting you.
attributes.name: The Pope

attributes.content: You don't seem surprised at all.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I can't say this was the result of any particular manipulation. The greatest lesson that I've learned in life is that people always cross paths, no matter their intention.
attributes.name: The Pope

attributes.content: But, in the end, we all have our own goals.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: The guardian, keeper, and executor of the most supreme law.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: The eleventh man to take the name of Yvangelista, the Patron Saint of Sacrifice and Unity, and to stand atop the Lateran Curia as the Apostle, His Holiness the Pope.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Why recite all these titles you do not believe in?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: The girl does not remain in your grasp.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: She's still young. There is still much for her to experience.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Yet we are old. So old that we know our way around conspiracy, political machination, and internal strife.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: What will you do now? Will you use this fine gift you spent decades preparing on her?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I'm not foolish enough to stand in a young girl's way.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Even if she triggered some kind of 'miracle?'
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: No, this miracle is Laterano's. It belongs only to Laterano. God's grace has fallen upon us. There is nothing more to it.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Do you enjoy history? I love history. For history to become history, you generally need an origin point, and when some kind of variable is introduced to stir up the water and form ripples—those ripples are history.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: What of the object that was thrown into the water in the first place, then? Perhaps history does not care about it.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: And neither do I.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: The girl called Cecelia will go where she wants and do what she wants. Some day in the future, perhaps the name Cecelia will be known far and wide—it could also remain forever in obscurity.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: But that has nothing to do with you or me.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: It has nothing to do with the both of us. We have a mutual understanding regarding that, do we not?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: You make yourself sound like a kind grandfather sending his granddaughter away.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: This is nothing more than you getting what it is that you seek. You now get to explain this miracle. In exchange, Cecelia earned the right to leave this place.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: This cannot even be called a trade. She never had the right to choose.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: No, I never wanted to do anything to her. Laterano has stood for millennia, and neither should it nor shall it ever waver for a mere mixed-blood child.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: I only hope that Apostles before and after you feel the same way, and that those expunged names were not erased for nothing.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: We cannot ask for too much. Sins shall always be sins. Only time can wear them down.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: And it wears them down to the point that no one remembers they were once sins.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I cannot cast blame on our forebears' cautiousness. However, neither shall I accept those sins in order to cover them up.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: So long as our mutual understanding stands, am I right?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Hmm... as I said, it is very boring to grow old. Thanks to all the things that we experienced in the past, we are always fearful, on the fence with just about everything.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: The old don't have the luxury of 'possibility,' Andoain. We have no choice but to continue down the path that was already laid.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: A path that was already laid...
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: That goes for you too. I know of your journey.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: My journey...
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Right, I once journeyed... and I heard the purest of prayers and the most vicious of curses.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I stepped into sumptuous palaces and plucked my shoes out of bloodstains.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I saw shameless sinners beg for mercy, and I closed the simplest of caskets on innocent children.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: It was always the same. Their cries always died down, and their tears always dried up, and I... I always stood there right next to them, attempting to comfort them.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I told them that salvation would come, as long as we believed.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: But no, nothing ever happened. Not even the briefest passing glance.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: The Holy City of Laterano has weathered every storm that came its way. How would a saint sitting in his soft armchair and the Sankta that know only to sing the praises of their own dignity know that there exist hardships in the lands beyond?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: All the hopeless penances, withered consolations, and deafening silences.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Do you know how heavily silence weighs on my heart?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I seek only an answer.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: We will never find salvation, will we?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: 'Salvation.' I often hear this word from the faithful, as though a sort of incomprehensible accedence, as though an ark that will rescue all the drowning.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Behold, our grand and glorious Lateran City. It is so splendid and magnificent, solemn and refined, with a perpetual aroma of vanilla and sugar wafting in its air.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: All of this is a reward for abiding by the laws. All of this is our proof of salvation.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Yet this paradise is only a paradise because of the harshness of the wastes beyond.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: We could have been a star in the barrenlands, a torch in the cold night!
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Don't you dare say I'm wrong! Laterano is not some ancient concept that floats only in scripture! It stands right here and now! Laterano can save everyone!
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: She cannot.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: And why is that?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Because we are only 'us.' Because we are the Sankta of Laterano.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: And 'they' are not 'us.' 'They.' They conceal, they become disillusioned, they consign, they become disappointed, they struggle, and they hate.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: They themselves mold and shape their own enemies. A man-eating monster of both lust and disgrace, with the flames of destruction hidden in its heart.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Why do you think these lands have seen countless dynasties and nations come and go in the flames of war while the miraculous Laterano has withstood the test of time?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Andoain, they are Inferno itself.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: And you, you chose to leave 'us.' You left behind the virtues that shaped us under the stubborn belief that your water could extinguish the flames of Inferno, that your candle could illuminate the night.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Why seek my answer? You chose despair for yourself long ago.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Three times have I visited Laterano. For the rest of my life I wandered the lands beyond.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I've met many men and women, and I do not need the Lateran Pope to tell me how dark their hearts can get. Yet there is also a ray of light in them. A radiant, blinding light that I can never forget.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: That I will never forget.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I was set ablaze by the light. Perhaps the fire is destined to be extinguished the moment it is first lit, but I could never again return to the eternally radiant Laterano.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Yet this perpetual radiance is cold and distant. Laterano's light shines on only a select few, and its might exists only to project this image of fabricated glory.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: In that case, I would rather be the torch that burns by the feet of those who are freezing to death.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Even if its flame will soon be extinguished.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Andoain, flames are destined to be extinguished. You seek to turn this perpetual light into a flame, and the flame will meet its fate one day. When that happens, there will be no more light, not even a cold and distant one.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: If you shatter the twin moons in the sky, then those struggling in the cold night will do so in darkness. Left only to close their eyes. Light will ultimately become a fantasy, a lie of a dream. Would you call eternal night a kindness?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: You despise the small size of this paradise.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: But do you know how hard it is for a small paradise to upon these lands?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: You scorn its small size, but have you ever considered that there are those who try to live an honest life? What right do you have to turn this paradise to tinder for that wildfire of yours, destined to be put out?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: This world is hostile to beauty. To allow this beauty to persist forever, do you know how much the Lateran people, countless Laterans, generations of Laterans have had to sacrifice?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Andoain, who are you to so handily deny all this with a few trivial words?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Preposterous.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: There are those trying to live an honest life in Laterano, but does that somehow make the lives of those outside any less real?!
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: They hold out hope despite their hardships, they follow the scriptures and the laws, they believe that they can change their lives, and they look forward to the rewards for their hard work.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Mrs. Baelen from the rock salt and sundries store, Deacon Landi of the Tidal Chapel, little Sagre, who ties the ropes on their bells...
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Tell me, is there anything wrong with their faith, with their hope?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Tell me, oh great and glorious Apostle, Pope Yvangelista XI, the great protector of our paradise and defender of history.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Why did Rocamarea deserve to be destroyed?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Answers.
Questions.
So this is the answer that I sought.
So this is the question that I wanted to ask.
Something has come loose.
Something that once had me tied up... for so long.
Something is roaring... struggling.
Yet I feel only at ease.
As though I'm bathing under the saliferous sunlight.
The gunshots rang out almost at the same time.
The law is carved into each Sankta's flesh and blood.
And one must pay a price to break it.
I knew that.
There is a bottomless abyss beneath my feet.
I've taken that step already.
A great force slams me into the wall, and the sculpted relief presses into my bones, with the statue behind me crumbling to the ground.
There is no question that it was the strength of a patron firearm.
Though Yvangelista XI's body is old and frail, he is far stronger than he seems.
However...
I try my best to open my eyes and make out his figure among the smoke and dust.
The old man is still standing in the middle of the Basilica, but there is no longer a smile on his face.
He looks even older than he did when I stepped into this place.
But the halo above his head shines as bright as ever—
'The law in our flesh and blood. The painful price to pay.'
Price...?
Then, I realized what the real question here is.
The halo above my head is not glowing any darker than it used to.
I see.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Both you and I came out of this unscathed. What a surprise. It's worthy of celebration, though.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: I was prepared to pay the price.
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: You're a pious follower, Andoain. Perhaps that is because you were not born in Laterano.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: In Laterano, we don't believe in our faith, do we? We live as part of faith itself.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: We Sankta have been its prisoner ever since the very moment the halos above our heads started to glow.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: It...? What exactly is this law that we... the Sankta believe in?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: What exactly... does it mean to fall...?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Throughout Laterano's long history, each apostle has had the authority to interpret the Commandments and derive from them new rules and decrees, even placing them above all others.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Laterano is built upon this law.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: All Sankta know: violate the rules, the Commandments, or the laws, and you must pay the price.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: The fallen Sankta are no longer connected to all other Sankta. Their patron firearms reject them.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Fallen Sankta are no longer Sankta.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: What 'is' a Sankta?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: A Sankta cannot point his firearm at another Sankta. That is a Commandment, and it is also our instinct, just like how a man cannot bring himself to take a step forward off the edge of a cliff.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Of course, there are those who can, and it seems to me you have more than earned the right to speak to that end.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: What makes me different from her?
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: I told you the Commandments are instinct, and I told you the Commandments are interpreted. Surely, a man of your intellect can tell those statements are mutually exclusive.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: If the law was constant, then the 'interpretations' that were added over time throughout our ever-changing history could never have been 'instinct.'
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Correct, but you are calling the wrong premise into question. The law is naturally constant... but our 'interpretation' isn't really as 'ever-changing' as you are making it seem.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Interpretation isn't a coincidence, Andoain. Do you understand?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: You said 'the old don't have the luxury of possibility.'
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: The law is much older than either of us.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: The apostle does not interpret the law. The law interprets itself. Why do you think the law is capable of this?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Take a look at these—Oh, my apologies. I made such a mess here—these structures, statues, stained glass, the exquisite domes and frescoes all around us.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Do they seem like they have constructed a particular illusion for us?
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Do you recall the 'Revelation?'
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: If we knew it to be absolutely temporal, even if we deconstructed it into ice cold, objective logic...
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Regrettably, man will still shine a spiritual light on it.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: There has only ever been one true law.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: —We are to continue our existence.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: Who are 'we?'
attributes.name: Andoain

attributes.content: Follow me.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.text: I follow the old man into the depths.
Everyone knows that the saints of old are buried under the Basilica.
They are the most knowledgeable and outstanding men and women in Laterano's long history. Their brilliant marble statues have no eyes, rendering them blind to those who pass by.
We head down.
Stela recounting the achievements of the past popes line our path.
Among them were the conceited, the noble, and perhaps even the crazed, but not a single one of them ever allowed Laterano to be besmirched. Now, they stand here in silence.
We head down.
This is where the oldest of saints lie.

They were the ones who plucked the Sankta out of chaos. They were the embodiment of all the virtues of mankind. All those who came after merely imitated them. The nameplates on which their miracles are described are dim and lightless.
We head down.
I do not know where I am.
For as far as my eyes can see, nothing here has never been mentioned in any texts or literature. I cannot understand any of this.
This should not be part of Laterano.
A low humming sound fills the entire space around us.
Strangely, I find myself flustered by all this.
It is not the answer that I sought. It is not something man is capable of establishing or interpreting...
It is not something that interpretations, analyses, debates, or reforms could influence...
It is not a matter of whether or not you believe in It, why you believe in It, or how you believe in It...
After all, this is an undisputable existence.
In such a manner...
It exists.
What is Laterano?
What are Sankta?
I see.
We are us only because—
It links us all together.
It molds us.
It is the criterion upon which all things are based.

attributes.content: The path you and I follow was paved by law.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: The paths you and I have trodden both lead to the same destination.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: It allows you and I to continue making our way forward.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI

attributes.content: This is the path It has deemed as correct.
attributes.name: Yvangelista XI
